channel.title: BBC News - Business

item.title: Inflation: Price rises see record jump as food costs soar in August
item.description: The UK inflation rate hit 3.2% in the year to August, according to the latest official figures.

item.title: FCA signs up celebrities to warn of investment risks
item.description: Influencers are part of the City regulator's plan to highlight decisions over high-risk investments.

item.title: Firms fined over 'frustrating' nuisance messages
item.description: We Buy Any Car, Saga and Sports Direct are fined for sending millions of nuisance messages.

item.title: John Lewis to create thousands of Christmas jobs
item.description: The partnership is looking to fill 7,000 temporary roles in shops, department stores and warehouses.

item.title: Countryside Properties scraps leasehold ground rent rises
item.description: Developer latest to drop clause campaigners say makes homes impossible to remortgage or sell.

item.title: Finance firms urge black students to apply for internships
item.description: A new work experience scheme is aiming to increase the number of black people working in finance.

item.title: Job vacancies: How do I find a new job and who is hiring?
item.description: There are record numbers of empty positions, figures show, so which sectors are looking to recruit?

item.title: Pennies back in production as cash is hoarded during Covid
item.description: No new 1p coins were made by the Royal Mint in 2018 and 2019 but production resumed last year.

item.title: ‘Improving my literacy helped me get a different job’
item.description: New research found that low levels of literacy costs workers an extra 18 months in lost earnings.

item.title: Mental health: TikTok rolls out support to combat suicide searches
item.description: The move comes as Instagram is facing fresh scrutiny over its impact on young people's wellbeing.

item.title: Canva: Australian online design platform valued at $40bn
item.description: The online design platform has become one of the most valuable private firms in the world.

item.title: Apple iPhone 13 brings portrait mode for video
item.description: The portrait-mode style video setting can pull focus on its subjects automatically.

item.title: Fashion house in backlash over 'racist' $1,190 sweatpants
item.description: Critics say the $1,190 pants, which come with a built-in pair of boxer shorts, rip off US hip hop culture.

item.title: Spain targets energy firms as European bills surge
item.description: Bills are spiralling in several countries and Spain agrees emergency measures to help consumers.

item.title: Why even giant ships can't solve the shipping crisis
item.description: A shortage of vessels is hampering global trade and may lead to empty shelves before Christmas.

item.title: Amazon's Cape Town base: The battle to save South African culture
item.description: Some indigenous groups say the planned office in Cape Town is on culturally important land.

item.title: The pressures - and rewards - of being an influencer
item.description: Running your own popular YouTube channel can be lucrative, but it comes with downsides.

item.title: The epicentre of Britain's pandemic house price boom
item.description: House prices have surged in many parts of the UK - and in one district they have risen by 29% in a year.

item.title: Could a reboot make social media a nicer place?
item.description: A Harvard University project will explore whether social media can be de-toxed

item.title: Women's state pension: 'It is like you've lived one big lie'
item.description: How women born in the 1950s had their retirement plans upended by state pension age changes.

item.title: How a monkey launched the pop-it toy craze
item.description: Why it took a TikTok primate to turn a forty-year-old idea into a global hit

item.title: The models that turned Instagram into their DIY catwalk
item.description: New York Fashion Week marks a tentative return - but how did supermodels keep working through Covid?

item.title: CEO Secrets: The bra boss busting stereotypes
item.description: Leanne Cahill, CEO of Bravissimo, shares her journey from shop floor to boardroom in retail.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.
